level1_survival.explanation: Short for 'Majime'. Used for emphasis or asking if something is true.
The ultimate universal word. Can mean 'dangerous', 'amazing', 'delicious', or 'terrible' depending on context.
Casual way to say 'very'. Used constantly in daily conversation.
From sumo term 'Gachinko'. Means totally serious or legitimate.
Short for 'One Chance'. Means 'there's a possibility' or 'maybe'.
Used when something is funny. Can be used dryly too.
Short for 'Kimochi warui'. Used to express disgust.
Literally 'highest'. Used when you feel great or something is perfect.
level1_survival.example: Kyou wa saikou (Today is the best)

level1_survival.explanation: Short for 'Uzattai'. Used when someone or something is bothering you.
Literally 'die', but used like 'I'm dead' in English for funny or cute things.
level1_survival.example: Kawaisugite shinu (It's so cute I'm dying)

level1_survival.explanation: Standard word for praise or surprise.
Short for 'Arienai'. Used when shocked or disappointed.
Used to show you understand or agree.
Military origin, now standard for 'OK'. Often abbreviated to 'Ri' („Çä) in text.
Casual version of 'Hontou'. Used to confirm truth.
To get cold feet or be startled.
Used when something is physically or mentally demanding.
Meaning you have room to spare. Used when something is easy.
Literally 'subtle', but implies 'not quite right' or 'mediocre'.
level1_survival.example: Aji wa bimyou (The taste is meh)

level1_survival.explanation: Normally means 'ordinary', but 'Futsuu ni oishii' means 'Actually pretty good'.
More casual/masculine pronunciation of 'Sugoi'.
Used when you feel sluggish or something is a pain to do.
Very common state of being.
Urging someone to be fast.
Used when someone is late or slow.
Used when not 100% sure.
Refusal. Also used when overwhelmed by cuteness (Muri... suki).
Universal.
Basic gratitude. Shortened to 'Ari' in texts.
Casual apology.

level2_otaku.explanation: The character or idol you support the most. Life revolves around Oshi.
level2_otaku.example: Oshi ga toutoi (My fave is precious)

level2_otaku.explanation: Literally 'noble'. Used when something is so pure/perfect it feels holy.
Falling deep into a fandom. 'Numa ni hamaru' (Stuck in the swamp).
level2_otaku.example: Kono anime wa numa da (This anime is a swamp)

level2_otaku.explanation: Strong affection for characters. Old school but still understood.
Archetype: Cold/hostile at first (Tsun), sweet later (Dere).
Supporting the whole group ('Box') rather than just one member.
level2_otaku.example: Watashi wa hako-oshi (I love the whole group)

level2_otaku.explanation: An episode of anime/show that was excessively good.
Genre where protagonist goes to another world. Very popular.
Someone fulfilling their 'Real' life (dating, friends). Enemy of Otaku.
Revealing the plot.
When animation quality drops terribly in an episode.
level2_otaku.example: Sakuga houkai shiteru (The animation is broken)

level2_otaku.explanation: The most popular/successful anime of the season.
Used for creators or performers who are incredibly talented.
level2_otaku.example: Sakusha wa kami (The author is a god)

level2_otaku.explanation: Short for 'Yami ga fukai' (The darkness is deep). Something has a dark secret.
level2_otaku.example: Kono sette wa yami-fuka (This setting is disturbing)

level2_otaku.explanation: Analyzing plot details deeply to predict outcomes.
Usually 'Fuseki kaishuu' (Foreshadowing payoff).
level2_otaku.example: Fuseki kaishuu ga sugoi (The payoff was amazing)

level2_otaku.explanation: A plot device. 'Death flag' (going to die), 'Love flag' (romance starts).
When the official creators provide content that fans (shippers) wanted.
Dying because something is too 'Toutoi' (precious).
Spreading the word about your 'Oshi' to get others into the swamp.
Usually 'Goi-ryoku ga nai' (No vocab), meaning you are so moved you can only say 'Sugoi'.
When official content or fanart matches your headcanon perfectly.
People who read the source material, unlike 'Anime-zei'.
level2_otaku.example: Watashi wa gensaku-zei (I read the manga)

level2_otaku.explanation: Seeing/playing something for the first time.
The end of the series. Often emotional.

level3_internet.explanation: Derived from 'w' (warai). Since 'wwww' looks like grass, people say 'Kusa'.
Used when someone does something nice or helpful in a game/stream. 'Big help'.
Short for 'Kachi kakutei'. When victory is certain.
level3_internet.example: Kore wa kachi-kaku (This is a sure win)

level3_internet.explanation: Used in FPS/Battle Royales. Enemy is 'one shot'.
Typo of 'Suki' that became standard internet slang.
Abbreviation for 'Google it yourself'. Old but gold.
Read Only Member. To read without posting.
level3_internet.example: Hantoshi ROMre (Lurk for half a year)

level3_internet.explanation: A very light, insincere apology. Short for 'Sumimasen'.
Used for great plays, or sarcastically for stupid ones.
'Aka' comes from Account. Getting banned.
Literally 'blazing up'. Getting massive backlash online.
Exposing someone's name/ID online to shame them.
Short for 'Otsukare'. Used at the end of games or streams.
Standard gaming praise. 'Naisu'.
Used when a teammate makes a mistake.
level3_internet.example: Donmai, tsugi ikou (Don't mind, let's go next)

level3_internet.explanation: Game error.
Can mean a bug fix or a balance adjustment.
Making a weapon/character weaker.
level3_internet.example: Tsugi no patch de nerf (Nerf in next patch)

level3_internet.explanation: Making a weapon/character stronger.
Using illegal tools. Or being unfairly strong.
Playing with random people, not friends. Like a 'stray cat' (Nora neko).
Playing with a full team of friends. Opposite of Nora.
level3_internet.example: Aite wa furupa da (Enemy is a full party)

level3_internet.explanation: Inactive player. Japanese gamers say 'Houchi' (Abandoned) too.
Literally 'Line dropped'. Internet disconnection.
An incredibly skillful move.
level3_internet.example: Mita? Ima no kami-play (Did you see that god play?)

level4_youth.explanation: From 'Emotional'. Used for sunsets, old songs, or sentimental vibes.
level4_youth.example: Kono kyoku emoi (This song is emo)

level4_youth.explanation: To relax, hang out at a cafe, or listen to lo-fi hip hop. 'Chiru suru'.
level4_youth.example: Cafe de chiru (Chilling at a cafe)

level4_youth.explanation: Sound of crying. Used lightly when something sad or happy happens.
level4_youth.example: Pien koete paon (Crying so much I'm an elephant)

level4_youth.explanation: 'Suki' (Like) + 'People'. Means the person you like or your partner.
level4_youth.example: Kyoo wa suki-pi to date (Date with my crush today)

level4_youth.explanation: Feeling like the new era (Reiwa). Modern, high-tech, or trendy.
level4_youth.example: Reiwa-kan aru ne (Feels very modern)

level4_youth.explanation: Literally 'tired', but used when overwhelmed by love ('Suki sugite shindoi') or just tired of life.
level4_youth.example: Maji de shindoi (I can't take this anymore / too good)

level4_youth.explanation: Playfully angry. 'I won't forgive you (for being too cute/lucky)'.
level4_youth.example: Hitori dake zurui, yurusan (No fair, won't forgive!)

level4_youth.explanation: Deeply understanding or agreeing. 'Wakarimi ga fukai' (Deep understanding).
level4_youth.example: Sore na, wakarimi (Exactly, I feel that)

level4_youth.explanation: Short for 'Hazukashii'. Used when you feel embarrassed or see something cringe.
level4_youth.example: Maji de hazui (Seriously embarrassing)

level4_youth.explanation: Sunny Character. People who are cheerful, popular, and outgoing.
level4_youth.example: Kare wa You-kya da (He is an extrovert)

level4_youth.explanation: Shadow Character. People who are quiet, otaku, or shy. Opposite of You-kya.
level4_youth.example: Watashi In-kya dakara (I'm an introvert, so...)

level4_youth.explanation: Short for 'Insta-bae'. Looks good in photos.
level4_youth.example: Kore wa bae (This is Insta-worthy)

level4_youth.explanation: Old internet slang, but still used by youth verbally or in text. 'Warota w'.
level4_youth.example: Sore wa warota (That made me laugh)

level4_youth.explanation: The ultimate agreement word. 'That is so true'.
level4_youth.example: A: Nemui (Sleepy). B: Sorena. (Same.)

level4_youth.explanation: Used when eating good food or seeing something amazing. 'I won'.
level4_youth.example: Ramen tabete yuushou shita (Ate ramen and won/felt great)

level4_youth.explanation: Same as Otaku slang, but used more broadly by youth for friends or idols.
level4_youth.example: Uchi no neko ga toutoi (My cat is precious)

level4_youth.explanation: Usually about food. 'I can eat this infinitely'.
level4_youth.example: Kore mugen ni ikeru (I can eat this forever)

level4_youth.explanation: From Shogi (Chess). Means you are in a hopeless situation.
level4_youth.example: Test benkyou shitenai, tsunda (Didn't study, I'm screwed)

level4_youth.explanation: Very strong emphasis. Stronger than 'Meccha'.
level4_youth.example: Bachikuso nemui (Insanely sleepy)

level4_youth.explanation: When something is beyond amazing.
level4_youth.example: Visual ga kamisugi (Visuals are too godly)

level5_persona.explanation: The most common pronoun for men. Sounds masculine and casual.
level5_persona.example: Ore ni makasero (Leave it to me)

level5_persona.explanation: Used by boys or polite men. Sounds softer and humbler than Ore.
level5_persona.example: Boku wa sou omou (I think so)

level5_persona.explanation: Standard for women. Also used by men in formal situations (business).
level5_persona.example: Watashi no namae wa... (My name is...)

level5_persona.explanation: Literally 'Self'. Used by athletes or soldiers. Sounds stoic and disciplined.
level5_persona.example: Jibun, bukyou desu (I am clumsy)

level5_persona.explanation: Originally Kansai dialect, now used by many young girls. Feels friendly.
level5_persona.example: Uchi ra saikou (We are the best)

level5_persona.explanation: Originally Kansai male, now standard Internet slang for 'Me'.
level5_persona.example: Wai no kachi (My win)

level5_persona.explanation: Used by country bumpkins or playful mascots. Sounds rustic or cute.
level5_persona.example: Oira ga yaru! (I'll do it!)

level5_persona.explanation: Famous because of Goku. Sounds wild, energetic, or countryside.
level5_persona.example: Ora wakuwaku suru zo (I'm getting excited)

level5_persona.explanation: Stereotypical pronoun for elderly men or wise masters.
level5_persona.example: Washi no deban ja (It's my turn)

level5_persona.explanation: Short for 'Atashi'. Used by female delinquents or tomboys.
level5_persona.example: Atai ni makashina (Leave it to me)

level5_persona.explanation: Archaic. Used by Samurai or Ninja characters. Ends sentences with 'degozaru'.
level5_persona.example: Sessha wa samurai degozaru (I am a Samurai)

level5_persona.explanation: Pompous or old-fashioned. Famous from 'I Am a Cat'.
level5_persona.example: Wagahai wa neko de aru (I am a cat)

level5_persona.explanation: Archaic. Used by princesses or high-class archaic characters.
level5_persona.example: Warawa wa manzoku ja (I am satisfied)

level5_persona.explanation: The Royal 'We'. Used by demon kings or emperors.
level5_persona.example: Yo wa ningen ga suki da (I love humans)

level5_persona.explanation: Very archaic and stiff. Used by clumsy but loyal samurai.
level5_persona.example: Soregashi no misu (My mistake)

level5_persona.explanation: Extremely arrogant. Adding 'Sama' (Lord) to oneself.
level5_persona.example: Ore-sama wa saikyou da (I am the strongest)

level5_persona.explanation: Edokko dialect. Humble commoner style.
level5_persona.example: Asshi ni wa wakarimasen (I wouldn't know)

level5_persona.explanation: Historically 'Self'. Used by merchants. *Warning: Can mean 'You' (Temee) in fights.*
level5_persona.example: Temae-domo (We humble people)

level5_persona.explanation: Internet slang. Calling oneself 'Mr. Me' to sound objective/funny.
level5_persona.example: Wai-shi, kyou mo zangyou (Mr. Me is working late again)

level5_persona.explanation: Very stiff/literary. Or used by Chuunibyou characters to sound cool.
level5_persona.example: Ware koso wa... (I am the one who...)
